descriptions.content:
"Clustered housing" is used as a particular building type within the Lhasa Atlas by Knud Larsen and Amund Sinding-Larsen. In the "Historical buildings in Lhasa" table at the back of the book (pp. 165-172), buildings of the "Clustered housing" type are designated with the letter "J" in the building type column. In the THL Place Dictionary, when a building has this feature type and the Lhasa Atlas is given as the source, it means that the building was designated with a "J" in the Lhasa Atlas table.

This building type is described as follows:

"J. Clustered housing. Example: Shöl East cluster (301-303).

"Lower social strata in Lhasa lived in simpler single-storey, mud brick buildings, often clustered with animal pens and outbuildings. Very few of this building type remain, with some examples in Shöl. They are in many respects similar to the traditional rural housing cluster" (p. 61).

Source:

Larsen, Knud and Amund Sinding-Larsen. The Lhasa Atlas: Traditional Tibetan Architecture and Townscape. London: Serindia Publications, 2001.
